clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of the Mechanical Peripheral Stimulation for Parkinson's Disease Rehabilitation
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of the Mechanical Peripheral Stimulation for Parkinson's Disease Rehabilitation - A Randomized Clinical Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Federal University of Health Science of Porto Alegre

clinical_study.source: Federal University of Health Science of Porto Alegre

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate safety and effectiveness of the peripheral mechanical stimulation of the feet on gait variables, clinical status, risk of falls, BDNF levels, immunological profile and brain functional connectivity changes in patients with Parkinson's disease.

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients will be submitted to 8 sessions of peripheral mechanical stimulation of the feet or sham stimulation along 4 weeks.
Evaluations will be performed before and after the first session, after the forth and the eighth session.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: Evaluated by means of the 3-D motion analysis system (BTS SMART DX 400).

secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated by means of the Timed Up & Go Test (TUG).
Evaluated by means of the Unified Parkinson Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS III).
Evaluated by means of the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI).
Evaluated by means of the Hoehn and Yahr scale.

arm_group.description: The feet mechanical stimulation will be given to all participants using GONDOLA equipment (Ecker Technologies Sagl, Switzerland). Intervention: Device: Foot Mechanical Stimulation (GONDOLA)
The sham stimulation will be given to all participants using GONDOLA equipment (Ecker Technologies Sagl, Switzerland). Intervention: Device: Foot Mechanical Stimulation (GONDOLA)
